feedback.p: Incorrect. Equilibrium is a term that means that everything is equal. In fact, things in the body are constantly changing, but generally within appropriate limits.
Correct. Relatively stable indicates that most of the time, values of the variables are near the set point, and if they vary, they don’t do so enough to cause dysfunction.

Although homeostasis is most commonly carried out by the many feedback loops, homeostasis is more about the general maintenance of stable conditions rather than the specifics of how that maintenance occurs.
Incorrect. Homeostasis maintains processes of the body.

body.p: At what levels is homeostasis maintained?

feedback.p: This is not quite right. Homeostasis is maintained at this level. For example, ions, water and other molecules are maintained at homeostasis using the urinary system. But homeostasis is maintained at other levels, too.
This is not quite right. Homeostasis is maintained at this level. For example, if cell number is not maintained, then tumors can form. But homeostasis is maintained at other levels, too.

This is not quite right. Homeostasis is maintained at this level. For example, after ingesting toxins, the liver can grow to compensate for the additional workload. But homeostasis is maintained at other levels, too.
Correct. With a constant influx of new material and changes in environmental conditions, the body works at every level to maintain homeostasis.

body.p: Which of the following would not be considered part of a homeostatic feedback loop for regulating plasma calcium concentration?

input.choice: hormones regulating free calcium in the bloodstream
kidneys removing extra calcium from the blood
moving calcium from the skeletal system into the plasma

feedback.p: Incorrect. Hormones often help regulate homeostasis.
Incorrect. The removal of excess calcium (usually by hormonal regulation of the kidneys) helps maintain homeostasis.

Correct. This may be confusing, since ingestion can increase the calcium in the body, but there is no internal process of the body that changes ingestion. Most people don’t “crave” calcium products, even if their calcium levels are low. However, regulatory molecules can increase the absorption of calcium in the digestive tract.
Incorrect. Hormonal regulation of bone calcium is the primary mechanism for calcium homeostasis.

body.p: Which is a common feedback mechanism to maintain homeostasis?

feedback.p: Correct. Negative feedback regulates most homeostasis. As one example, when we are cold, we shiver to increase our temperature. That’s negative feedback: we work to “undo” the cold by increasing heat generation.

Incorrect. Positive feedback can help maintain homeostasis, but only in emergency situations. Negative feedback regulates most homeostasis. As one example, when we are cold, we shiver to increase our temperature. If this situation were regulated by positive feedback, we would be cold and then our body would regulate to make us colder.
Incorrect. While both positive and negative feedback are used to maintain homeostasis, positive feedback is typically only used in emergency situations and is therefore less common.
Incorrect. Homeostasis is most often maintained with negative feedback. Occasionally, in emergency situations, positive feedback is used.

body.p: What physiological processes are regulated by positive feedback?

input.choice: only pathological (or disease) processes have positive feedback
there are no biological examples of positive feedback

feedback.p: Incorrect. Normal physiological processes are usually regulated by negative feedback.
Correct. Normal physiological processes are usually regulated by negative feedback, but some emergency processes, such as blood clotting, are regulated by positive feedback.
Incorrect. Many pathological processes have positive feedback, but not all positive feedback processes are pathological, for example, lactation and other aspects of birth.
Incorrect. There are many examples of positive feedback in biology.

body.p: What would happen if positive feedback were used in the cruise control system in a car?

input.choice: you would speed up until the engine failed or you would slow down until you stopped
you would maintain a constant speed

feedback.p: Correct. Cruise control usually works via negative feedback to keep a car moving at a constant speed. However, with positive feedback, an increase in speed would cause the cruise control to further increase speed until the engine failed. Similarly, a slight decrease in speed would cause the cruise control to slow down the car until it stopped.

Incorrect. Cruise control usually works via negative feedback to keep a car moving at a constant speed. However, with positive feedback, an increase in speed would cause the cruise control to further increase speed until the engine failed. Similarly, a slight decrease in speed would cause the cruise control to slow down the car until it stopped.
Incorrect. Both positive and negative feedback usually occur as a process or series of small steps, not abrupt changes.

content.p: Consider the following positive feedback loop of platelets and clotting:

Blood clotting (or coagulation) begins with damage to the lining of blood vessels. Platelets flowing in the blood stick to the vessels to form a clot and become activated. Then platelets release serotonin, adenosine diphosphate (ADP), and thromboxane, which attract other platelets to the wound.

multiple_choice.body: What will ultimately occur if this cascade continues uninterrupted?

input.choice: every platelet in the body will go to the clot or the vessel will become occluded
the clot will reduce in size over time

response.feedback: Correct. Positive feedback will continue to amplify the effect until "failure."
Incorrect. That is what would happen if this were a negative feedback loop.
Incorrect. The opposite would happen; entire vessels would be occluded by clots.
Incorrect. The opposite would happen; every platelet would be activated.

multiple_choice.body: What is a cell type involved in the clotting process?

response.feedback: Correct. Platelets are called minicells.
Incorrect. A blood vessel is a tissue.
Incorrect. Thromboxane is a lipid secreted by platelets.
Incorrect. A clot is an aggregate of cells and proteins.

multiple_choice.body: What is a potential medical problem associated with this positive feedback cycle?

response.feedback: Correct. Cardiovascular disease can cause a clot, or a thrombus, inside blood vessels, leading to a complete blockage or occlusion.
Incorrect. The opposite is true; a thrombus can lead to a complete vessel blockage or occlusion.
Incorrect. Thrombus formation is the problem.
Incorrect. This is possible, after complete blockage or occlusion, but thrombus formation is the problem.

it prevents platelet signaling to other platelets

response.feedback: Incorrect. Platelets will still adhere, but the positive feedback cascade is inhibited.
That is not quite right. Initial platelets will still activate and adhere, but the positive feedback cascade to other platelets is inhibited.
Correct. Initial platelets will activate and adhere, but the positive feedback cascade to other platelets is inhibited.
Incorrect. Thromboxane signals platelets.

multiple_choice.body: What other organ system strongly contributes to total body fluid homeostasis?

response.feedback: Correct. The urinary system helps regulate total body fluid by monitoring excretion.
Incorrect. In some ways the movement of the muscular system can generate heat and may cause a slight loss of water, but this is indirect.
Incorrect. The skeletal system is responsible for support.

multiple_choice.body: What can result from ingestion of unrestricted amounts of water?

input.choice: good health; water is good for you

response.feedback: Incorrect. Most people don’t consume enough water. However, too much of something can be as harmful as too little of it; that is why homeostasis maintains a "set point."
Incorrect. The body will have problems, but positive feedback loops will not occur; this is still a negative feedback process, but the effectors cannot keep up with the input.

response.feedback: Correct. When cells are not able to regulate homeostasis, a tumor can form.

body.p: Heart rate commonly changes in response to challenges to the body, yet there is no direct sensor for heart rate. This would suggest that heart rate is:

feedback.p: Incorrect.
Incorrect.
Correct. Heart rate is a response the brain uses to control blood pressure. If heart rate increases, the blood pressure also increases. If heart rate decreases, blood pressure also decreases.

input.choice: (A) There are multiple feedback loops for regulating blood pressure.
(B) The control center integrates information from all sensors.

Both A and B could be correct.

feedback.p: Incorrect.
Incorrect.

Correct. Multiple sensors mean there are more than one mechanism to regulate blood pressure. Blood pressure is affected by heart rate, blood volume, and blood vessel diameter.
